node.title: Wonking Out: Is the Great Resignation a Great Rethink?
node.description: Maybe workers realized how bad their jobs were.
node.content: ["Life is full of surprises. But there are surprises, and then there are surprises.", "What I mean is that most of the time, when something you weren\u2019t anticipating happens, you quickly realize that it\u2019s something you could and maybe even should have seen coming, at least as a possibility. Of course air traffic control delays caused me to miss my connection. Or, to take an economistic example, few anticipated the 2008 financial crisis, but once it happened economists realized that it fit right into both their theoretical frameworks and historical patterns.", "Sometimes, however, events take a turn that leaves you wondering what\u2019s going on even after the big reveal.", "Right now the U.S. economy is experiencing a very old-fashioned bout of inflation, with too much money chasing too few goods. That is, booming demand has collided with constrained supply, so prices are rising.", "But there are really two kinds of supply constraint out there, and some are more comprehensible than others.", "Not many people anticipated the now famous supply-chain issues \u2014 the ships steaming back and forth waiting to be unloaded, the parking lots stacked high with containers and the warehouses that have run out of room. But once they began happening, those issues made perfect sense. Consumers who were afraid to buy services \u2014 to eat out, to go to the gym \u2014 compensated by buying lots of stuff, and the logistical system couldn\u2019t handle the demand.", "On the other hand, the Great Resignation \u2014 the emergence of what look like labor shortages even though employment is still five million below its prepandemic level, and even further below its previous trend \u2014 remains somewhat mysterious.", "Unlike the \u201cskills gap\u201d invoked to explain persistent unemployment after the 2008 crisis, this time labor shortages seem to be real. Workers are quitting at record rates, an indication that they feel confident about finding new jobs. Wages are growing at rates normally associated with the peak of a boom. So workers are clearly feeling empowered, even though many fewer Americans are employed than in the past. Why?", "Earlier this year many people insisted that enhanced unemployment benefits were reducing the incentive to accept jobs. But those extra benefits were eliminated in many states as early as June, and nationally in early September; this cutoff doesn\u2019t seem to have had any measurable effect on employment or labor force participation.", "Another story, which is harder to refute, says that the extensive aid families received during the pandemic left many with more cash on hand than usual, giving them the financial space to be choosier about their next job.", "A less upbeat story says that some employees are still afraid to go back to work, and/or that many can\u2019t go back to work because their child care arrangements are still disrupted.", "But there\u2019s at least one more possibility (these things aren\u2019t mutually exclusive): The experience of the pandemic may have led many workers to explore opportunities they wouldn\u2019t have looked at previously.", "I\u2019d been thinking vaguely along these lines, but Arindrajit Dube, who has been one of my go-to labor economists throughout this pandemic, recently put it very clearly. As he says, there\u2019s considerable evidence that \u201cworkers at low-wage jobs [have] historically underestimated how bad their jobs are.\u201d When something \u2014 like, say, a deadly pandemic \u2014 forces them out of their rut, they realize what they\u2019ve been putting up with. And because they can learn from the experience of other workers, there may be a \u201cquits multiplier\u201d in which the decision of some workers to quit ends up inducing other workers to follow suit.", "I like this story, in part because it dovetails with one of the main discoveries of behavioral economics \u2014 namely, that people have a strong status quo bias. That is, they tend to keep doing what they were doing even when there might be much better alternatives. Famously, workers are far more likely to enroll in retirement plans when they have to check a box to opt out than when they have to check a box to opt in. Checking that box costs nothing, yet many people will fail to take advantage of a good deal unless enrollment is automatic.", "So I can easily believe that there were many workers who should have quit their lousy jobs in, say, 2019, but didn\u2019t because they weren\u2019t really considering the alternatives. And it\u2019s at least possible that the disruptions of the pandemic led to a great rethink.", "Of course, we don\u2019t know this. But if that\u2019s part of what\u2019s happening, it\u2019s actually a good thing \u2014 a small silver lining to the horrors of Covid-19."]
